verb.description: Grasp or seize suddenly and roughly.
examples: she grabbed him by the shirt collar
she grabbed her keys and rushed out

verb.description: Attract the attention of; make an impression on.

noun.description: A quick sudden clutch or attempt to seize.
examples: he made a grab at the pistol

noun.description: A mechanical device for clutching, lifting, and moving things, especially materials in bulk.

phrases: Heaps of prizes are up for grabs, and it is open to all ages and styles for soloists, duos and bands.
There are some fantastic prizes up for grabs so get dressed up and come along.
A winner will be drawn at each meeting and there are a variety of attractive prizes up for grabs.
There is a top prize of £100 up for grabs for the best amateur photograph of the festival.
origin: Late 16th century: from Middle Low German and Middle Dutch grabben; perhaps related to grip, gripe, and grope.
